properties.areaDesc: Shoshone/Lava Beds; Arco/Mud Lake Desert; Upper Snake River Plain; Lower Snake River Plain; Eastern Magic Valley; Raft River Region; Marsh and Arbon Highlands; Franklin/Eastern Oneida Region; Blackfoot Mountains; Caribou Range; Beaverhead/Lemhi Highlands; Lost River Valleys; Lost River Range; Big Lost Highlands/Copper Basin
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 7:46PM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
properties.description:
At 741 PM MST, an broad area of moderate to heavy snow was located
across the Arco Desert, central to lower Snake Plain, and adjacent
highlands, moving slowly east. Webcams, surface weather stations,
and traffic data indicate visibilities in this area are dropping as
low as one-half mile at times with snow accumulating on roadways.

Locations impacted include...
Idaho Falls, Pocatello, Blackfoot, American Falls, Arco, McCammon,
Lava Hot Springs, Chubbuck, Ammon, Shelley, Aberdeen, Iona, Inkom
and Firth.

Snow may accumulate at a rate of one half inch to one inch per hour
in this area of moderate to heavy snow. Be prepared for hazardous
driving conditions. Consider delaying travel if possible. If you
must travel, slow down, leave plenty of extra space between you and
other vehicles, and allow extra time to reach your destination.

NWSheadline: MODERATE TO HEAVY SNOW RESULTING IN SLICK TRAVEL CONDITIONS AND POOR VISIBILITY THIS EVENING

properties.headline: Winter Storm Warning issued November 28 at 5:45PM AKST until November 30 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
properties.description:
CCA

* WHAT...Heavy snow expected with blizzard conditions possible.
Total snow accumulations of 6 to 8 inches. Visibility less than
one quarter mile possible at times. Winds gusting to 50 mph.

* WHERE...Chukchi Sea Coast.

* WHEN...From 3 PM Tuesday to 6 PM AKST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow
could significantly reduce visibility. Large snow drifts may
form.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The strongest winds and lowest visibility
are expected late Tuesday night.
properties.instruction:
A Winter Storm Warning for snow means severe winter weather
conditions are expected or occurring. This will make travel very
difficult or impossible.

properties.areaDesc: Waters from Cape Shoalwater WA to Cape Falcon OR from 10 to 60 nm; Waters from Cape Falcon to Cape Foulweather OR from 10 to 60 nm; Waters from Cape Foulweather to Florence OR from 10 to 60 nm
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued November 28 at 6:40PM PST until November 29 at 1:00PM PST by NWS Portland OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Gale Warning, seas building to 15 to 17 ft at 12
seconds and southwest winds 25 to 35 kt with gusts up to 45 kt
expected. For the Small Craft Advisory, seas 9 to 13 ft at 13
seconds and west winds 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.

* WHERE...Portions of South Washington, North Oregon coastal
waters.

* WHEN...Gale Warning, from 1 PM Tuesday to 10 AM PST Wednesday.
Small Craft Advisory, until 1 PM PST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds will cause hazardous seas which could
capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.
properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

properties.areaDesc: Columbia River Bar
properties.headline: Gale Warning issued November 28 at 6:40PM PST until November 30 at 4:00AM PST by NWS Portland OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Rough bar conditions expected. General seas will be 10 to
12 ft early tonight subsiding to 6 to 8 ft late tonight into
early Tuesday before climbing to 14 to 16 ft Tuesday night. Seas
will build to 11 to 13 ft during the strong ebb current of 5.67
kt at 755 PM Monday. Seas will build to 10 to 12 ft during the
ebb current of 4.95 kt at 901 PM Tuesday. Expect south winds to
increase to 20 to 30 kt with gusts to 45 kt when the Gale
Warning is in effect.

* WHERE...In the Main Channel of the Columbia River Bar.

* WHEN...Gale Warning, from 4 PM Tuesday to 4 AM PST Wednesday.
Small Craft Advisory, until 2 AM PST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds will cause hazardous seas which could
capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.
properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

properties.areaDesc: Laguna Madre From the Port Of Brownsville to the Arroyo Colorado; Laguna Madre From The Arroyo Colorado To 5 NM North Of Port Mansfield TX; Laguna Madre From 5 nm North Of Port Mansfield To Baffin Bay TX; Coastal waters from Port Mansfield TX to the Rio Grande River out 20 NM; Coastal waters from Baffin Bay to Port Mansfield TX out 20 NM
properties.headline: Gale Watch issued November 28 at 8:16PM CST until November 30 at 9:00PM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Dense Fog Advisory, dense fog will reduce
visibility to less than 1 NM. For the Gale Watch, northeast
winds 20 to 30 kt with gusts up to 35 kt and seas 7 to 10 ft
possible.

* WHERE...Laguna Madre between the Port of Brownsville and
Baffin Bay, and Nearshore Gulf waters between the mouth of the
Rio Grande and Baffin Bay from 0 to 20 nm.

* WHEN...For the Dense Fog Advisory, until 2 AM CST Tuesday. For
the Gale Watch, from Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday
evening.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds can cause hazardous seas which could
capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility. Low
visibility will make navigation difficult.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Dense Fog Advisory may need to be extended
beyond 2 AM.
properties.instruction:
Mariners should consider altering plans to avoid possible
hazardous conditions.  Remain in port, seek safe harbor, alter
course, and/or secure the vessel for severe wind and seas.

If you must navigate, proceed with caution. Use proper fog
signals. Make sure all running lights are on. Remember to use
your radar and compass.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 6:45PM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
Surface observations and satellite images indicate that fog has
developed along the portions of Lower Texas Coast this evening.
Reported visibilities have been somewhat variable, but generally
ranging from 1 to 3 miles, but with a few locations will see
dense fog with visibilities of a quarter of a mile at times.

Be sure to drive with caution by using your low beam headlights
and allowing plenty of space between your vehicle and the vehicle
in front of you.

NWSheadline: PATCHY TO AREAS OF FOG ALONG THE LOWER TEXAS COAST THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway; City and Borough of Juneau
properties.headline: High Wind Warning issued November 28 at 3:43PM AKST until November 29 at 9:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
properties.description:
* WHAT...Northeast winds 30 to 40 mph with gusts 60 to 70 mph
expected.

* WHERE...Skagway, Klondike Highway, and Downtown Juneau and
Douglas.

* WHEN...From 3 AM to 9 PM AKST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Damaging winds could blow down trees and power
lines. Widespread power outages are possible. Travel will be
difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Very strong winds will develop early
Tuesday morning as Arctic high pressure strengthens over the
Yukon and British Columbia, and a low pressure system moves
south over the eastern Gulf of Alaska. Areas where the highest
winds will occur include Skagway and Downtown Juneau. Winds
diminish Tuesday night as the low in the south of the AK Gulf
weakens. Wind chills to 40 below near Skagway and White Pass.
properties.instruction:
A high wind warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Use caution if you must travel. Protect exposed
skin and limit exposure to very cold temperatures on the Klondike
Highway.

* WHERE...Valdez and Thompson Pass.

* WHEN...From 9 PM this evening to 9 PM AKST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...High winds may move loose debris, damage property,
and cause power outages. Travel will be difficult, especially
for high profile vehicles.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Cold air, an upper-level shortwave, and
strong winds in the upper atmosphere will combine and allow
for high winds to develop this evening and gradually decrease
Tuesday evening.
properties.instruction:

around or damaged by the wind. Prepare for the possibility of
widespread power outages. Use caution if you must drive.

properties.areaDesc: Upper Koyukuk Valley; Yukon Flats and Surrounding Uplands; Central Interior; Middle Tanana Valley; Deltana and Tanana Flats; Denali
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 3:29PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
properties.description:
A strong weather system in Russia will move east across the
Interior on Wednesday and Wednesday night. This is expected to
bring 3-7 inches of snow to most of the Eastern Interior Wednesday
and Wednesday night, including the Fairbanks area.

As much as a foot of snow is possible along the North Slopes of
the Alaska Range from Denali Park West.

Snow is expected to taper off on Thursday.

NWSheadline: Siginifcant Snow Possible Wednesday And Wednesday Night

properties.areaDesc: Coastal Waters From Cape Flattery To James Island Out 10 Nm
properties.headline: Gale Warning issued November 28 at 4:28PM PST until November 29 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Seattle WA
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Gale Warning, southeast winds 30 to 40 kt and
seas 8 to 10 ft at 13 seconds. For the Small Craft Advisory,
east winds 15 to 25 kt.

* WHERE...Coastal Waters From Cape Flattery To James Island Out
10 Nm.

* WHEN...For the Gale Warning, from 7 AM to 10 PM PST Tuesday.
For the Small Craft Advisory, from 10 PM this evening to 7 AM
PST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds will cause hazardous seas which could
capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.
properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occurring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

properties.areaDesc: Bear River Range; Caribou Range
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 28 at 5:19PM MST until November 29 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
properties.description:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches.

* WHERE...The Bear River Range and Caribou Range, including but
not limited to Emigration Summit, Wayan, and Swan Valley.

* WHEN...Until 5 AM MST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Blowing and drifting
snow could make travel difficult.
properties.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

The latest road conditions can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

NWSheadline: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 AM MST TUESDAY

properties.areaDesc: Sawtooth/Stanley Basin; Sun Valley Region
properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 28 at 5:19PM MST until December 2 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
properties.description:
...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY FOR CURRENT STORM HAS EXPIRED...

* WHAT...1 inch or less of additional snow accumulation is
expected this evening, thus the Winter Weather Advisory has been
allowed to expire. For the next winter storm late Wednesday
morning through early Friday morning, heavy snow is possible.
Total snow accumulations of 10 to 20 inches are expected, with
locally higher amounts to 2 feet near the peaks and ridges of
the Sawtooth Mountains. While light snow will start Wednesday
morning, the heaviest snow is expected to start late Wednesday
night.

* WHERE...The Sawtooths, Stanley Basin, and Sun Valley region,
including but not limited to Banner Summit, Stanley, Galena
Summit, Ketchum, and Sun Valley.

* WHEN...From late Wednesday morning through early Friday morning.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult, especially during the
Thursday morning and Thursday evening commutes. Wind gusts in
excess of 30 MPH near mountain highway passes as well as peaks
and ridgelines may also result in areas of blowing and drifting
snow and dangerous conditions in the backcountry.
properties.instruction: Monitor the latest forecasts for updates on this situation.

NWSheadline: WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY FRIDAY MORNING FOR NEXT APPROACHING STORM

properties.areaDesc: Frank Church Wilderness; Big Lost Highlands/Copper Basin; Wood River Foothills

properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 12
inches with locally higher amounts possible. While light snow
will start Wednesday morning, the heaviest snow is expected to
start late Wednesday night.

* WHERE...The Wood River Foothills, Frank Church Wilderness, Big
Lost Highlands, and Copper Basin areas, including but not
limited to Hailey, Bellevue, Picabo, and Clayton.

* WHEN...From late Wednesday morning through early Friday morning.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult, especially during the
Thursday morning and Thursday evening commutes. Wind gusts in
excess of 30 MPH near mountain highway passes as well as peaks
and ridgelines may also result in areas of blowing and drifting
snow and dangerous conditions in the backcountry.
properties.instruction: Monitor the latest forecasts for updates on this situation.

NWSheadline: WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY FRIDAY MORNING

properties.areaDesc: Eastern Curry County and Josephine County
properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 28 at 4:18PM PST until December 1 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible above 3000 feet. Total snow
accumulations of 6 to 15 inches possible. Winds could gust as
high as 35 mph across exposed higher terrain.

* WHERE...Mountains in eastern Curry County and Josephine County
above 3000 feet. This includes Bear Camp Road.

* WHEN...From Wednesday morning through Thursday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The
hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening
commute.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heaviest snow is expected Wednesday
night. Snow levels will start out near 4000 to 4500 feet,
lowering to 3000 feet by late Wednesday evening. Snow levels
may lower further down to 2000 feet Thursday morning.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
properties.instruction:
* Stock emergency kit with tire chains, flashlight, batteries,
blankets, food, water, and medications.

* The safest place during a winter storm is indoors.

* Plan now to avoid traveling during the storm.

* A Winter Storm Watch means there is potential for significant
snow accumulations that may create dangerous travel.

NWSheadline: WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON ABOVE 3000 FEET

properties.areaDesc: Central Siskiyou County
properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 28 at 4:18PM PST until December 1 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 5 to
10 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph in the
Shasta Valley and over the mountains.

* WHERE...This includes areas in the Shasta Valley from Gazelle
south and elevations above 3000 feet in central Siskiyou
County. This includes Interstate 5 near Weed and Gazelle and
highway 97 east of Weed.

* WHEN...From Wednesday afternoon through Thursday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The
hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening
commute. Blowing snow may reduce significantly reduce
visibility and create near white out conditions at times.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heaviest snow is expected late Wednesday
evening through Thursday morning. Moderate snow of 2 to 5
inches is possible near Yreka and Montague.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
properties.instruction:
* Stock emergency kit with tire chains, flashlight, batteries,
blankets, food, water, and medications.

* The safest place during a winter storm is indoors.

* Plan now to avoid traveling during the storm.

* A Winter Storm Watch means there is potential for snow
accumulations that may create dangerous travel.

properties.areaDesc: Western Siskiyou County
properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 28 at 4:18PM PST until December 1 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible above 3000 feet. Total snow
accumulations of 8 to 18 inches except locally higher amount
up to 24 inches over the higher mountains above 5000 feet.
Winds could gust to 30 to 45 mph over exposed higher terrain.

* WHERE...Western Siskiyou County above 3000 feet. This includes
higher portions of Sawyers Bar Road and higher portions of
highway 3 west of Yreka and from Callahan south.

* WHEN...From Wednesday afternoon through Thursday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Patchy
blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The
hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening
commute.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heaviest snow is expected Wednesday
evening through Thursday morning. Snow levels will start out
around 4000 feet Wednesday afternoon, lowering to 3000 feet
Wednesday night. Snow levels may lower further down to 2000
feet Thursday morning.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
properties.instruction:
* Stock emergency kit with tire chains, flashlight, batteries,
blankets, food, water, and medications.

* The safest place during a winter storm is indoors.

* Plan now to avoid traveling during the storm.

* A Winter Storm Watch means there is potential for significant

properties.areaDesc: South Central Oregon Cascades; Siskiyou Mountains and Southern Oregon Cascades
properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 28 at 4:18PM PST until December 1 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Light snow showers will taper off tonight. Heavy snow
possible Wednesday morning through Thursday afternoon. Total
snow accumulations of 10 to 20 inches possible. Winds gusting at
30 to 50 mph over exposed higher terrain.

* WHERE...The advisory includes South Central Oregon Cascades
and Southern Oregon Cascades from Howard Prairie Lake
northward and highways 62, 138, 140, and 230. The winter storm
watch includes all areas in the South Central Oregon Cascades,
Southern Oregon Cascades, and Siskiyous and includes
Interstate 5 near Siskiyou Summit and portions of highways 62,
66, 138, 140, and 230.

* WHEN...From Wednesday morning through Thursday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Patchy
blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Gusty
winds could bring down tree branches.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heaviest snow is expected Wednesday evening
through Thursday morning.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
properties.instruction:
* Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.

* Carry tire chains and be prepared for snow covered roads and
limited visibilities.

* See https://www.tripcheck.com or http://quickmap.dot.ca.gov for
latest road conditions.

* A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means that periods of snow
will cause travel difficulties.

NWSheadline: WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON ABOVE 3000 FEET... ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY HAS EXPIRED

properties.areaDesc: South Central Siskiyou County; North Central and Southeast Siskiyou County; Northeast Siskiyou and Northwest Modoc Counties; Modoc County; Klamath Basin; Northern and Eastern Klamath County and Western Lake County
properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 28 at 4:18PM PST until December 1 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations 5 to 10
inches except higher amounts of 10 to 20 inches in the south-
central and southeast Siskiyou County area including near
Mount Shasta City and from Tennant south. Winds are expected
to gust to 25 to 35 mph and locally to around 45 mph over the
mountains.

* WHERE...This includes south-central and eastern Siskiyou
County and Modoc County in California and Klamath and western
Lake Counties in Oregon. This includes the communities of
Mount Shasta, Dunsmuir, McCloud, Tennant, Dorris, Tulelake,
Klamath Falls, Chemult, Newell, Canby and surrounding areas.
This also includes Interstate 5 near Mount Shasta City, and
portions of highways 97, 66, 62, 140, 139, 299, 395 and 31.

* WHEN...From Wednesday afternoon through Thursday evening.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Areas
of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Heavy
wet snow may result in trees down and power outages. The
hazardous conditions could impact the morning and evening
commute.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heaviest snow is expected late Wednesday
evening through Thursday afternoon. Moderate to heavy snow
could continue into Thursday evening.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
properties.instruction:
* Stock emergency kit with tire chains, flashlight, batteries,
blankets, food, water, and medications.

* The safest place during a winter storm is indoors.

* Plan now to avoid traveling during the storm.

* A Winter Storm Watch means there is potential for significant
snow accumulations that may create dangerous travel.

properties.areaDesc: Anchorage; Matanuska Valley
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 2:56PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
properties.description:
Recent cold conditions have caused area rivers and streams to
increase water levels due to freeze-up. Localized bankfull
conditions to minor flooding with buildup of bank ice is possible
along smaller creeks and streams. River levels will stop
increasing when ice cover is more complete upstream.

NWSheadline: COLD AIR MOVING INTO THE AREA WILL BRING FREEZE UP ON STREAMS AND WATERWAYS IN THE ANCHORAGE BOWL AND THE MAT-SU VALLEY

properties.areaDesc: Natrona County Lower Elevations
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 28 at 4:55PM MST until November 29 at 8:00AM MST by NWS Riverton WY
properties.description:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 3 inches.
Higher amounts are possible along the south side of Casper and
in the foothills of Casper Mountain.

* WHERE...Natrona County Lower Elevations.

* WHEN...Until 8 AM MST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult. The hazardous conditions
could impact the evening and morning commutes.
properties.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling. If you must travel,
keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in your vehicle in case
of an emergency.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

properties.areaDesc: Laguna Madre From the Port Of Brownsville to the Arroyo Colorado; Laguna Madre From The Arroyo Colorado To 5 NM North Of Port Mansfield TX; Laguna Madre From 5 nm North Of Port Mansfield To Baffin Bay TX; Coastal waters from Port Mansfield TX to the Rio Grande River out 20 NM; Coastal waters from Baffin Bay to Port Mansfield TX out 20 NM
properties.headline: Marine Weather Statement issued November 28 at 5:52PM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
Patchy to areas of fog continue across the bays and nearshore
waters along the Lower Texas coast early this evening.
Visibilities will generally range from 2 to 3 miles with some
locations dropping below 1 mile at times.

If you must navigate, proceed with caution. Use proper fog
signals. Make sure all running lights are on. Remember to use
your radar and compass..

NWSheadline: PATCHY TO AREAS OF FOG LINGERING ALONG THE COAST

properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Small Craft Advisory, northwest winds 15 to 20
kt with gusts up to 30 kt and seas 3 to 5 feet. For the Gale
Watch, west winds 20 to 30 kt with gusts up to 40 kt and seas
4 to 7 feet possible.

* WHERE...Cape Cod Bay and Massachusetts Bay and Ipswich Bay.

* WHEN...For the Small Craft Advisory, until 1 AM EST Tuesday.
For the Gale Watch, from Wednesday afternoon through Thursday
evening.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds can cause hazardous seas which could
capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.
properties.instruction:
Mariners should consider altering plans to avoid possible
hazardous conditions.  Remain in port, seek safe harbor, alter
course, and/or secure the vessel for severe wind and seas.

THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE
COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.

* WHAT...Avalanche Warning

* WHERE...Park Range, Elk Head Mountains, Flat Top Mountains, Elk
Mountains and West Elk Mountains.

* WHEN...Dangerous avalanche conditions will begin Monday night
November 28 and will last through Tuesday November 29

* IMPACTS...Dangerous avalanche conditions exist in the backcountry.
Heavy snow and strong winds will result in widespread avalanche
activity. Human triggered avalanches are very likely.
properties.instruction:
Avoid travel on and under all
steep slopes. Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended.
Consul www.colorado.gov/avalanche for detailed information.

properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 28 at 2:36PM PST until December 1 at 7:00AM PST by NWS Portland OR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 1 to 2
feet possible. Winds could gust as high as 40 mph.

* WHERE...Northern Oregon Cascades.

* WHEN...From late Tuesday night through Thursday morning.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
properties.instruction:
Monitor the latest forecasts for updates on this situation.

A Winter Storm Watch means there is a potential for significant
snow, sleet, or ice accumulations that may impact travel. Continue
to monitor the latest forecasts.

NWSheadline: WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY MORNING

properties.areaDesc: Ventura County Mountains; Los Angeles County Mountains
properties.headline: Wind Advisory issued November 28 at 2:30PM PST until November 29 at 6:00AM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
properties.description:
* WHAT...Southwest to west winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 50
mph, shifting to northwest to north overnight.

* WHERE...Ventura County Mountains and Los Angeles County
Mountains.

* WHEN...Until 6 AM PST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions expected with road debris
and crosswinds. Unsecured objects will be blown around. Tree
limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Interstate 5, Highways 33 and 14 impacted.
properties.instruction:
Use extra caution when driving, especially if operating a high
profile vehicle. Secure outdoor objects.

properties.areaDesc: La Garita Mountains Above 10000 Ft; Eastern San Juan Mountains Above 10000 Ft
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 28 at 3:22PM MST until November 29 at 5:00PM MST by NWS Pueblo CO
properties.description:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow expected. Total snow
accumulations of up to to 9 inches. Winds gusting 60-70 mph.

* WHERE...Eastern San Juan Mountains and La Garita Mountains above
10000 feet.

* WHEN...From 5 PM this afternoon to 5 PM MST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Blowing snow could
significantly reduce visibility over high mountain passes. Cold
wind chills as low as 25 below zero could cause frostbite on
exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.
properties.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

indoors.

properties.headline: Gale Warning issued November 28 at 3:57PM EST until December 1 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Gale Warning, west winds to 40 knots with 8 to 12
foot waves. Small Craft Advisory, south winds 15 to 25 knots
with gusts up to 35 knots and waves 3 to 6 feet expected.

* WHERE...St Joseph to Manistee.

* WHEN...For the Gale Warning, from midnight Tuesday night to 4
AM EST Thursday. For the Small Craft Advisory, from 7 PM this
evening to midnight EST Tuesday night.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds will cause hazardous waves which could
capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds will increase to gale force around
midnight Tuesday night.
properties.instruction:
Mariners should alter plans to avoid these hazardous conditions.
Remain in port, seek safe harbor, alter course, and/or secure the
vessel for severe conditions.

properties.areaDesc: Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Lake Tahoe Area
properties.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued November 28 at 12:53PM PST until December 2 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 10 to 16
inches, except 14 to 26 inches above 7000 feet possible, highest
along the Sierra crest. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph in
valley locations with gusts above 100 mph along the Sierra
crest.

* WHERE...Greater Lake Tahoe Area.

* WHEN...From Wednesday evening through Friday morning.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous
conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Strong
winds could cause damage to trees and lead to power outages.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heaviest snowfall rates are anticipated
on Thursday. The combination of heavy snow and wind may bring
periods of whiteout conditions.
properties.instruction:
Now is the time to prepare an emergency kit for your home and
car. If traveling consider alternate plans, remember to carry
tire chains, extra food, water and clothing. Once the storm
arrives, travel may be difficult or impossible for an extended
period of time.

properties.areaDesc: New Buffalo MI to St Joseph MI; Michigan City IN to New Buffalo MI
properties.headline: Gale Warning issued November 28 at 3:49PM EST until December 1 at 1:00AM EST by NWS Northern Indiana
properties.description:
* WHAT...For the Gale Warning, west winds 20 to 25 knots with
gusts up to 40 knots and waves 7 to 10 feet expected. For the
Small Craft Advisory, south winds 15 to 20 knots with gusts up
to 30 knots expected.

* WHERE...Michigan City IN to St Joseph MI.

* WHEN...For the Gale Warning, from 1 AM Wednesday to 1 AM EST
Thursday. For the Small Craft Advisory, from 7 AM Tuesday to 1
AM EST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds will cause hazardous waves which could
capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.
properties.instruction:
Mariners should alter plans to avoid these hazardous conditions.
Remain in port, seek safe harbor, alter course, and/or secure the
vessel for severe conditions.

NWSheadline: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM TO 6 PM CST TUESDAY

properties.areaDesc: Northeast; Culebra; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands
properties.headline: High Surf Advisory issued November 28 at 4:24PM AST until November 30 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous surf conditions and rip currents expected due
to breaking waves around 6 to 10 feet.

* WHERE...Beaches of northeastern Puerto Rico from Loiza to
Fajardo, Culebra, and St.Thomas and St. John in the northern US
Virgin Islands.

* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, through 6 AM AST Wednesday.
For the High Risk of Rip Currents, through late Wednesday
night.From 6 PM AST this evening through late Tuesday night.

* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions along with
localized minor coastal flooding and beach erosion. Strong
currents that can carry even the best swimmers away from shore
and out to sea.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Long-period northerly swell will spread
across the local Atlantic waters through Wednesday,
deteriorating coastal and surf zone conditions.
properties.instruction:
There is a high risk of rip currents.

Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away
from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the
sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties
and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and
signs.

If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain
calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for
help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to
shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to
swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly.

A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

properties.areaDesc: Oswego; Jefferson
properties.headline: Lakeshore Flood Watch issued November 28 at 3:17PM EST until December 1 at 4:00PM EST by NWS Buffalo NY
properties.description:
* WHAT...Significant lakeshore flooding possible.

* WHERE...Oswego and Jefferson counties.

* WHEN...From Wednesday evening through Thursday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...The combination of high lake levels and significant
wave action may result in lakeshore flooding along the
immediate lakeshore, especially in bays, inlets, harbors, and
other low lying areas along the shoreline. Shoreline erosion
is also possible.
properties.instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Watch means that conditions favorable for
lakeshore flooding are expected to develop. Residents on or near
the shore should take action to protect property, and listen to
local radio, television, or NOAA Weather Radio for later
statements or warnings.

properties.areaDesc: Wasatch Mountains South of I-80
properties.headline: Winter Storm Warning issued November 28 at 1:04PM MST until November 29 at 7:00PM MST by NWS Salt Lake City UT
properties.description:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 10 to 20
inches, locally higher in the Cottonwood Canyons.

* WHERE...Wasatch Mountains South of I-80.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM MST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Winter driving conditions are expected across all
mountain routes including both the Monday evening and Tuesday
morning commutes. Traction laws may be enacted.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...An area of moderate to heavy snow is
expected near and behind a cold front this afternoon into this
evening. Periods of snow will continue through the overnight
hours. There is the increasing likelihood that portions of the
Cottonwood Canyons will see periods of moderate to heavy snow in
association with a lake band impacting eastern Salt Lake County
Monday night into Tuesday morning.
properties.instruction:
If you must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in
your vehicle in case of an emergency.

For graphical depictions of the snowfall forecast, including
Official NWS Forecast, High End Amount, and Low End Amount, visit
weather.gov/slc/winter.

For winter road conditions from the Utah Department of
Transportation, visit
http://www.udottraffic.utah.gov/roadweatherforecast.aspx or dial
511.

* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 5
inches across western Salt Lake County, 4 to 8 inches across
eastern Salt Lake County, locally higher.

* WHERE...Salt Lake Valley.

* WHEN...Until 2 PM MST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Winter driving conditions are expected. The hazardous
conditions will impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning
commute across portions of Salt Lake County.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A band of moderate to heavy snow is
expected to cross Salt Lake County later this afternoon into
this evening and will impact the Monday evening commute. This
band will last 1 to 2 hours, with additional light snow through
the remainder of the evening. A lake effect snow band is
expected to develop after midnight and continue through 9 AM to
as late as 11 AM Tuesday morning. Periods of moderate to heavy
snow will bring additional snow accumulations to locations
impacted by this band, currently most likely to impact portions
of southern and eastern Salt Lake County.
properties.instruction:
If you must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in
your vehicle in case of an emergency.

For graphical depictions of the snowfall forecast, including
Official NWS Forecast, High End Amount, and Low End Amount, visit
weather.gov/slc/winter.

For winter road conditions from the Utah Department of
Transportation, visit
http://www.udottraffic.utah.gov/roadweatherforecast.aspx or dial
511.

properties.headline: Rip Current Statement issued November 29 at 5:59AM ChST until December 4 at 6:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
properties.description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.

* WHERE... East facing reefs of the Marianas.

* WHEN...Through Sunday afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water.
properties.instruction:
Swim near a lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and
float. Don't swim against the current. If able, swim in a
direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the
shore and call or wave for help.

properties.description:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding during the overnight high tide.

* WHERE...Lower and Middle Keys.

* WHEN...Through Tuesday morning.

* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets
and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some
seawalls and docks will be overtopped. Boaters can expect less
clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that
persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost
certain to contain a mix of saltwater.
properties.instruction: Do not drive through flooded roadways.

* WHERE...Southwest corner of Imperial County and Western
Imperial County.

* WHEN...Until 7 AM PST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Difficult driving conditions, especially for larger
vehicles traveling along roads with crosswinds. Light, unsecured
objects may become airborne. Minor tree damage possible.
Localized areas of blowing dust possible as well.
properties.instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that sustained wind speeds of between
30 and 40 mph are expected, or wind gusts of between 40 and
58 mph. Winds this strong can make driving difficult, especially
for high profile vehicles. In addition, strong winds over desert
areas could result in briefly lowered visibilities to well under
a mile at times in blowing dust or blowing sand. Use extra
caution.
